captions.text: [Intro Music]

I know by this point you&#39;ve all
trained yourselves to not hear the phrase

&quot;subscribe to our Patreon&quot; alongside
&quot;got any spare change&quot; and let me tell you

what the mainstream
media is covering up about 9-11.

But how&#39;s this for an incentive? The
top tier of Escapist Patreon subscribers get

to vote on what retro game I
do a ZP on when summer rolls around,

the AAA release schedule gets
patchier than the wifi in a North Korean gulag, and

this time the honour
goes to Chrono Trigger, narrowly

beating out Danganronpa
in the last round of voting.

Yeah, sorry weebz. The previous
generation of weebz beat you to the punch. But

don&#39;t let it get you down,
just cope by telling yourself the

same thing you say after
every American political election.

Maybe next year enough old people
will have died. But anyway. Ah, Chrono Trigger.

The retro SNES Japanese RPG that can
make life very awkward if you find yourself

having to very quickly think of a
rhyme for it in a high stakes rap battle.

Happily for me, I&#39;d already played it
long ago, but I made sure to refresh myself

last week with the Steam version in
case any fresh revelations came to mind.
Well one did. Steam releases of retro

16-bit games really
aren&#39;t getting any better.

Is it so hard to believe we want the
chonky pixel resolution to be consistent like
the original? Oh, don&#39;t be silly, Yachts.

Obviously you want all
the interface text in teeny weeny

vision in case the ants on
your office floor want to get involved.

Yeah, I should probably pick up that
toffee apple. The Steam version also has a few

full-on anime cutscenes for a couple
of very arbitrarily chosen action sequences.

A holdover, I assume, from some
port or other, maybe for the PS1 or some
long-forgotten failed early 32-bit system

that used discs the
size of 18-wheeler hubcaps.

And it&#39;s always an awkward lurch when
the Dragon Ball Z episode ends and we hard

cut back to the characters doing the
exact same thing again but in artfully fudged

mode 7 SNES pixels
where everyone&#39;s only got two

expressions, neutral and
surprised, and slapping their bum.

Actually, that&#39;s not true. I can&#39;t rip
on Chrono Trigger for its pixel art because

it&#39;s actually one of
the better-looking 16-bit games.

And as much as that
sounds like saying &quot;it&#39;s very

architecturally sound for a
Duplo project&quot;, I genuinely mean that.

Compare it to Final Fantasy VI where
every single character&#39;s based on the same

basic look that resembles a
chronically overdressed lemming.

Every character in Chrono Trigger has
a distinct stance and subtly different emotes

into animations that convey a lot of
personality, so that one character gets a

surprising amount of mileage
out of the slapping her bum animation.

But we get ahead of ourselves. If
you&#39;re used to having your eyeballs physically

abused by modern Japanese RPGs with
their 20-hour tutorials and interfaces like the

modern art on the
walls of the euthanasia clinic,

it&#39;s refreshing how
stripped-down Chrono Trigger feels in retrospect.

Here&#39;s your dude, here&#39;s
a sword, here&#39;s four different

kinds of magic. Fire, water,
light, dark, and that&#39;s your lot.

Anyone who says they need more than
that is just patting their expense claim.

&quot;Yeah, I know you heard
me, Persona 5. Get out of here

with that nuclear shit.
That&#39;s just fire with a PhD.&quot;

And it&#39;s a nice understandable plot
that doesn&#39;t feel the need to throw you into

the middle of a tense
political situation that you

need ten minutes with the
in-game glossary to understand.

Although the plot it does have
initially comes across like that of a knockoff

goosebumps book being described over
the phone by an editor who just got off the

Back to the Future
ride at Universal Studios.

&quot;I was just an ordinary kid till I
went to the fair where my friend who&#39;s good with

a wrench and therefore has the
ability to build a fully functional teleporter

accidentally sent me back to medieval
times and now I need to rescue a princess or

my girlfriend will
be erased from history.&quot;

And also there&#39;s a
frog. That&#39;s good stuff, Robert,

but we might need to
work on cutting the title down.

As plots go, it&#39;s got a decent hook,
but then it&#39;s all resolved at the end of the

first act and there&#39;s still
another 15 hours a game to fill.

And I wouldn&#39;t say the subsequent
story holds up to its promising opening.

We return the princess and get
mistaken for a kidnapper and there&#39;s a rather

beautifully done sequence where the
player is morally judged for a few seemingly

innocuous choices
at the start of the game.

But after the prison break, the
characters basically just go &quot;Ah bollocks to this,

we&#39;re out&quot; and randomly gat about time
for a bit before the game goes &quot;Oh shit, we

need a plot. Uh, giant evil god
wants to destroy the world. There we go.&quot;

So here we are again, teenagers
using the power of friendship to kill God, the

point all JRPG plots end up
at if you let them go on long enough.

It doesn&#39;t help that the main
characters frequently feel like outsiders to the plot

after having such a
strong presence in the first bit.

The princess love interest, who set
the entire story in motion, I eventually drop

from the regular party in favour of
the robot for their strong range of attacks,

and the cavewoman for the way her
buttocks bounce up and down as she runs.

There&#39;ll be a major cutscene where an
evil queen sacrifices her daughter to summon

the big baddie and Chrono
and his mates are just sorta there.

Like Sora, Donald and
Goofy, awkwardly standing to one

side while Elsa from
Frozen&#39;s doing a big musical number.

All in all, I have a feeling Chrono
Trigger is one of those fondly remembered games

that people will often go back to
and replay the first few hours of, but don&#39;t

often get around to
replaying the rest of so much.

You know, System Shock 2 Syndrome.
The gameplay goes downhill after a while, too.

The simplicity that is to its credit
early on becomes the proverbial friendly dog

in the sterile
operating room, when the game has few

options for escalation
beyond just giving enemies more health.

So the later boss fights are just
about repeating the same sequence of attacks and

heals for 45
minutes, and getting buggered over

an ironing board if
your concentration ever slips.

I was having real trouble with
this giant robot boss around the midpoint.

I don&#39;t know who this giant robot dude
thought he was in the context of the plot or

what I&#39;d done to upset him, but he
showed up without a word and got off three free

magic attacks in a row
that sucked all my health off like

your mum with an ice
lolly, which seemed very unreasonable.

Until I remembered the Steam version
had a speed setting for combat, and stupidly

I&#39;d set it to fast, thinking it would
hurry up all those elaborate special attack

animations that he&#39;d have
to sit through 9 billion times.

But turns out it just shortens the
amount of reaction time you&#39;re given to rummage

through the menus as part of the
active time battle thing that was Squaresoft&#39;s

opening salvo in the afore-discussed 
decades-long effort to very slowly

transition to Final
Fantasy XVI&#39;s real-time combat.

But I think I hear the rhythmic
scraping of the retro snobs getting their stabbing

knives ready, so let me clarify
that Chrono Trigger was always one of the few

16-bit JRPGs that could instantly
grab me purely from music visuals&#39; presentation

and pure sense of adventure, and
it&#39;s hardly fair to piss on it for points that

were, let&#39;s face it, par for
the course for the genre at the time.

Still, it would be nice if newer
JRPGs could mix things up a bit. Maybe end with

20-somethings using the power
of middle management to maim the Pope.
[Outro Music]
